summary: Persepolis, written by Marjane Satrapi, is a graphic memoir that chronicles the author’s childhood and early adulthood in Iran during the Islamic Revolution and the Iran–Iraq War. Through stark black-and-white illustrations, Satrapi explores personal and political upheaval, the struggle for identity, and the resilience of hope amid conflict.

events.title: Street Protests Start
events.description: Marjane, now age 9, watches crowds brawl with police in the streets of Tehran, now face to face with the revolution.

events.title: Islamic Republic Established
events.description: The Shah falls; Ayatollah Khomeini returns. Iran begins to transform, but will freedom remain?

events.title: Iran–Iraq War Starts
events.description: Bombs rain on Tehran and Marjane’s city goes from protest to siege with tragic losses and destruction sure to follow.

events.title: Veil Enforcement
events.description: Girls must now wear the veil in school; Marjane begins to resist this, showing a feminist spark.

events.title: Punk & Rebellion
events.description: Underground punk bands like The Coup begin, and thus Marjane finds new ways to rebel musically.

events.title: Sent to Austria
events.description: To keep her safe, Marjane’s parents ship her off to Vienna, uprooting her life once again.

events.title: Exile
events.description: Alone in Europe, Marjane struggles with identity as she wonders where she truly belongs... if anywhere.

events.title: Return
events.description: Back in Iran as an adult, Marjane confronts her roots as she wonders how she has become the woman that she is.
